description:
Chryseolinea serpens is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes. It is a Gram-negative, obligately anaerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. Chryseolinea serpens is typically rod-shaped and exhibits a serpentine or undulating morphology, which has contributed to its species name "serpens" meaning "serpent-like" in Latin.

This bacterium is considered a member of the normal gut microbiota in some animals, including humans. It has been isolated from various environmental sources, such as soil and aquatic sediments. Chryseolinea serpens is known to be involved in the degradation of complex organic matter, particularly cellulose and hemicellulose, through the production of various hydrolytic enzymes.

The specific ecological roles and metabolic capabilities of Chryseolinea serpens within the microbial communities it inhabits are still under investigation. Further research is needed to fully understand the diversity, distribution, and functional significance of this bacterial species in different environments and host organisms.
